entry.title: An Atypical Life
entry.content:
Today I happened to read the following blog post, written by David Caoin on his blog Raptitude.com. As blogs posts of this type typically do, it struck a nerve with me. The difference today is that I’m talking action as a result.

Of particular relevance in the post are thoughts such as “it took me a long time to learn that typical is no good”. Or “having higher standards than what’s typical doesn’t mean you thing you’re better than everyone else. It only means everyone is running way below their capability, and you want to make up some of the distance”.

So what is atypical for me:

  1. I want to build

entry.title: 2013 My Year in Review
entry.content:
I’m beginning to write this post on January 14, 2013, one year early.

What do I want to achieve this year, in order of importance:

  1. Pay off approximately $70,000 of personal debt.

    Measures?
    Rewards?

  2. Maintain a healthy diet and exercise regimen.

    Measures?
    Rewards?

  3. Achieve the freedom of a passive income source based around my passions.

    Measures?
    Rewards?

January

January began with a wimper. After a fun holiday season, I finally got serious about striving to attain my goals mid-month. This blog post is the documentation of the latter.

After losing 30 pounds in 2012 and improving my overall health and diet by moving to a Paleo/slow-carb way of eating, I’d managed to let things slip and by mid-January had gained back 8lbs. The weight gain was no mystery, as I’d been drinking quite a bit of beer and had let my way of eating slip. As a measure of my fitness, I’d been running a familiar 10KM route throughout 2012 and had seen my time for that run decrease to below 50 minutes at it’s best. On January 13th, I ran that same route in 1:01:30.

Disappointed in myself, I decided to commit to run a minumum of 3 days per week. I also joined EverdayLegendary and began using the forum.

February
